docs.snippet: How to find an errant attachment....
docs.lead_paragraph: If you are mystified over where a spreadsheet or document is - was it an attachment to Gmail or a Google Doc? -Gmail Labs has a time-saving solution called Apps Search. To turn it on, log in to your Gmail account on the Web, click the green Labs icon (or click Settings and then the Labs link). Scroll down to Apps Search and click the button next to Enable the features. Then click on the Save Changes button. The search box in the Gmail window now says Search Mail and Docs - and lets you look in both places at once for that elusive file.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Where Is That Attachment?

docs.lead_paragraph: Consumer Watchdog, a consumer group, has long been critical of Google and some of the comments that Eric Schmidt, the company's chief executive, has made about privacy online. On Thursday, the group took its objections to a new level with a 540-square-foot video advertisement in Times Square in New York that shows Mr. Schmidt as an unctuous ice cream truck driver who knows everything about everyone and happily offers free ice cream in exchange for full body scans. (The video is available on YouTube, which is owned by Google.)

docs.snippet: Even you can learn to trust, Google has more tips on getting more out of Gmail's Priority Inbox....
docs.lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Google introduced a  Gmail feature that sorts incoming mail -- not the spam, but the stuff you actually want -- into important and unimportant messages. The Priority Inbox is a super-inbox that, based on your own past behavior with e-mail, places what it calls "important and unread" messages at the top of the list. For example, it could flag a shipping notice that contains a FedEx tracking number from an online retailer as important, while pushing the same merchant's weekly newsletter down into the less-important section.

headline.main: Three New Tricks for Gmail's Priority Inbox

docs.abstract: Even you can learn to trust, Google has more tips on getting more out of Gmail's Priority Inbox.

docs.snippet: SOMMER--William. With great sadness we announce the passing of William Sommer, cherished husband of Frances Sommer Anderson, adored father of Thea Sommer, father-in-law of Maria DiPietro-Sommer, loving Grandpa to Benjamin and Jeremy--the ice cream...
docs.lead_paragraph: SOMMER--William. With great sadness we announce the passing of William Sommer, cherished husband of Frances Sommer Anderson, adored father of Thea Sommer, father-in-law of Maria DiPietro-Sommer, loving Grandpa to Benjamin and Jeremy--the ice cream kids. He passed due to complications of a heart attack. A quintessential New Yorker known for love of baseball, number theory, history of New York City and the world, he regaled people in his favorite Chelsea joints with "long" anecdotes, corrected their grammar, and directed them to Google "watermelon sneakers"! We will remember him for his work ethic and refusal to "lie down and take it." In his Montecristi hats, assorted caps, and books tucked in the back of his pants, his saunter could be recognized at a distance. A gathering, Celebrating Bill's Life, will be held on Sunday, September 19, 11-3, Community Room, 343 8th Ave. at 27th St. Donations to Greenberg Division of Cardiology NYP-Weill Cornell Hospital.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMMER, WILLIAM

docs.snippet: Lately, stories about Google often seem to be stories about conflict -- Google knocking heads with China or the Justice Department or Facebook.     For Eric E. Schmidt, Google's chief executive, that is a good sign. ''This is winning,'' he said th...
docs.lead_paragraph: Lately, stories about Google often seem to be stories about conflict -- Google knocking heads with China or the Justice Department or Facebook. For Eric E. Schmidt, Google's chief executive, that is a good sign. ''This is winning,'' he said this week, speaking to a group of reporters at Google's Zeitgeist conference in Arizona. ''If we were losing, we would not have these problems.''

headline.main: Conflict as a Sign of Google's Success

docs.snippet: Mobile devices work on different operating platforms, and market share has been shifting in the last year. Research In Motion's share has dropped, but it still leads the pack with its BlackBerrys, carried along by ardent business fans. Equally ent...
docs.lead_paragraph: Mobile devices work on different operating platforms, and market share has been shifting in the last year. Research In Motion's share has dropped, but it still leads the pack with its BlackBerrys, carried along by ardent business fans. Equally enthusiastic iPhone users made Apple one of only two platforms to gain. Google developed its opeating system, Android, as open-source software, and it comes on smartphones like the Ally, above, from LG and Verizon, and the Evo 4G, made by HTC for Sprint. Android-based devices have shown the biggest gain. Wireless companies are constantly looking for that sweet spot to entice customers: the right texting plan, the perfect price point for the latest smartphone, and a mix of cool new apps. SHELLY FREIERMAN

docs.snippet: Imagine getting a bit lost in, say, Manchester, England, pointing your cellphone at a nondescript building and learning instantly that you've chanced across a legendary pub that opens 30 minutes from now -- and, by the way, a nearby rare-vinyl sho...
docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine getting a bit lost in, say, Manchester, England, pointing your cellphone at a nondescript building and learning instantly that you've chanced across a legendary pub that opens 30 minutes from now -- and, by the way, a nearby rare-vinyl shop is offering a 20 percent discount, today only. Oh, and just down the block is a bistro that is never mentioned in guidebooks but is beloved by locals. Welcome to the new, hyper-connected, technology-based travel paradigm. It's the era of the smartphone as ubiquitous tool of navigation, when what matters is not just the here but the now. With smart phones increasingly ubiquitous, a new era of hyper-connected travel is at hand--literally--as so-called location-awareness continues to explode as a cultural/tech meme. Google Maps and Google Street View blanket more and more of the planet. Facebook and Twitter allow users to ''geotag'' their updates with specific geographic coordinates, while Foursquare turns ''checking in'' into a form of entertainment. Users of the photo-sharing site Flickr geotag more than four million photos per month. And augmented reality (AR) technology, which allows travelers to navigate their way to nearby attractions by aiming a smartphone in any direction, weaves together all those geodata points into a miniaturized virtual world coated with zesty little information bubbles.

headline.main: Horizon Wireless

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study confirms what some in the technology industry have long sensed: that Apple commands an inordinate amount of the media's attention. A yearlong look at technology news coverage by the Pew Research Center's Project for Excellence in Journalism found that 15.1 percent of tech articles were primarily about Apple; 11.4 percent were about Google; and a meager 3 percent were about Microsoft.

headline.main: Tech Talk: Google and Its Rivals

docs.abstract: Google and its rivals, a tiny tablet and a roundup of tech news are in this week's podcast.

docs.snippet: Gmail will allow users to turn off the conversation view, one of the features that makes it most different from competitors like Outlook....
docs.lead_paragraph: When Gmail was introduced back in 2004, one feature was particularly mind-bending for people who were used to traditional e-mail inboxes. Instead of showing each message separately, Google threaded conversations into one conversation.

headline.main: Freedom From Threaded Conversations in Gmail

docs.abstract: Gmail will allow users to turn off the conversation view, one of the features that makes it most different from competitors like Outlook.

docs.snippet: Google has been told by Dave McClure to get out the checkbook and buy Twitter: "Whatever your math is, you better do it soon, because you're getting killed by Facebook."...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dave McClure has some advice for Google: Get out the checkbook and buy Twitter -- and make it snappy.

headline.main: McClure to Google: Buy Twitter

docs.abstract: Google has been told by Dave McClure to get out the checkbook and buy Twitter: "Whatever your math is, you better do it soon, because you're getting killed by Facebook."

docs.snippet: Typing the name of a Senate candidate into Google usually reveals "for senate" or "wiki" as the top item in the list via the search engine's 'autocomplete' function. But not always....
docs.lead_paragraph: Begin typing into a Google search box and you will quickly see a list of suggested searches. Google describes this feature, known as autocomplete, as "a reflection of the search activity of all Web users." For example, typing the name of a Senate candidate usually reveals "for senate" or "wiki" as the top item in the list. But not always. Below, the first suggestions that appeared this week for some candidates.

headline.main: Autocomplete the Candidates

docs.abstract: Typing the name of a Senate candidate into Google usually reveals "for senate" or "wiki" as the top item in the list via the search engine's 'autocomplete' function. But not always.

docs.snippet: Google Instant's blacklist; getting hired at D.E. Shaw; why an M.B.A. won't buy you a job....
docs.lead_paragraph: --Google Instant's blacklist, and its attempt to kill Charlie Brooker. Ah well, he can always turn it off.

headline.main: Morning Take-Out

docs.abstract: Google Instant's blacklist; getting hired at D.E. Shaw; why an M.B.A. won't buy you a job.
